text.p: The concentration of greenhouse gases (GHG) in the atmosphere causes global temperatures to rise with a host of impacts and catastrophic consequences. At the moment we are heading for a rise in excess of 3°C this century. It is a global average covering extreme variations across regions and seasons. According to the IPCC we will see more severe and frequent extreme weather events in the near future like floods, droughts, wildfires and hurricanes. A fraction of a degree in average global warming can have massive consequences.
The UNEP Climate Action Dashboard[a] shows you the global state of the climate emergency with its impact on extreme weather events across the world

article.title: Land temperature
article.alt: This world map shows land temperature anomalies compared to the average conditions during that period between 2000-2008.
article.head: Actual temperatures on land[b]

text.p: When average global temperatures rise, it covers vast differences across the world and throughout the year. The extreme weather events will get more severe and more frequent with rising temperatures. To stay safe the world must limit temperature rise to 1.5°C by cutting 30 gigatonnes of GHG emissions annually by 2030.

article.title: Ocean temperature
article.alt: This world map shows the temperature of the top millimeter of the ocean's surface. Sea surface temperature influences weather, including hurricanes, as well as plant and animal life in the ocean.
article.head: Actual temperatures in the oceans[c]

text.p: Oceans are absorbing 90% of the heat and a third of the GHG emissions. It has slowed the visible impacts of a warming planet yet it is leading to warmer and more acidic waters affecting marine life and ecosystems as well as the communities relying on them for livelihoods.

article.title: Fires
article.imgtitle: A decade of fires (monthly data from 2010 to 2021)
article.alt: This world map shows a decade of burning fires. Fire plays a major role in Earth's carbon cycle by releasing carbon into the air, and by consuming trees that would otherwise absorb carbon from the air during photosynthesis.
article.head: Wildfires around the world [d]

text.p: With average global temperatures on the rise, local and seasonal variations mean that droughts and heatwaves are causing more severe and more frequent wildfires. Burning vast areas of forests is laying waste to ecosystems, biodiversity and people. It is also emitting further CO2 and affecting the economy and human health. To stay safe the world must limit temperature rise to 1.5°C by cutting 30 gigatonnes of GHG emissions annually by 2030.

text.p: The maps were produced using imagery by the NASA Earth Observations team using data courtesy of the MODIS Land Science team at NASA Goddard Space Flight Center.
The sea surface temperature map shows an estimate of the warmth of the ocean's "skin" (top millimeter).
The land temperature map shows temperature anomalies of the "skin" of the land surface for a given month compared to the average conditions during that period in 2001-2010.
The animated fire map shows the locations of fires over the past decade.
The maps were recolored and reprojected to the Equal Earth projection.
